awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Optical and System Engineering Interrogation of Vascular Amyloid in Alzheimer's Disease
awd_abstract_narration:
Alzheimer's disease is a devastating condition which has no cure and only some treatments for symptoms are available that do not stop the progression of the disease. This disease is the 6th leading cause of death in the United States and the only one among the top 10 that cannot be prevented, cured or even slowed. The objective of this project is the development of the essential technologies to study the effect of Alzheimer's on the vascular network of the brain.

A main cause of Alzheimer's disease is the accumulation of a protein, called amyloid-beta in the brain tissue. Deposits of this substance form skeletal structures around the blood vessels which prevent the vessels from dilating and delivering enough oxygen and energy to active cells. This condition damages the nerve cells and contributes to the initiation or progression of the disease. The team will design and develop imaging technologies which allow the study of this specific effect in unprecedented details. They will use the collected data to develop computer algorithms to predict the state and progression of the disease based on the acquired images.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The main objective of this proposal was the development of essential technologies and algorithms to systematically study cerebral blood flow regulation and neurovascular dysfunction in Alzheimer’s disease. Accumulation of amyloid-B in the brain tissue is the pathological hallmark of Alzheimer’s. In Alzheimer’s disease, deposits of amyloid-B precipitate around the tubular structure of cerebral vessels which is a pathology known as the vascular amyloid angiopathy. Vascular amyloid directly correlates with the reduction of cerebral blood flow associated with Alzheimer’s which causes ischemic damage to neurons and contributes to the initiation or progression of the disease. The project main focus was the study of neurovascular coupling in healthy and Alzheimer's animal models.

The project had three separate phases. Phase one was system development for experiments, phase two was conducting experiments with healthy animals to understand and document the response of the vascular network to neural stimulation onsets, phase three was conducting experiments with animal models of Alzheimer's to clarify differences between the vascular response to neural activation onsets caused by the disease.

In phase one, a new optoelectronic platform was developed for the experiments by integrating four technologies including spectral-domain optical coherence tomography for in-vivo angiography and tracking of vascular responses, optogenetic stimulation to non-invasively stimulate neurons, 2-photon microscopy and transparent electrocorticography (ECoG) to record induced neural activity in the tissue under test. All hardware and software of this platform were developed in the lab. Next, a large number of experiments were conducted in healthy animals to measure the response of the vascular network to different neural stimulation configurations. Collected data was analyzed and a mathematical framework was developed to model neurovascular coupling in fine details. We showed that the developed model could predict the response of the vascular network and changes in blood flow to neural stimulations of different configurations. The model was tested and the precision of the prediction was measured. We also used the model to develop closed-loop blood flow controllers that could manipulate the delivery of blood to different brain regions based on commands sent from a computer.  Results of this work were published in two major journal publications in the journal of neural engineering. After finishing the modeling task we entered the third phase of the project. Phase three itself had two main tasks. Task one was the development of animal models of Alzheimer's needed for the experiments. We should have also crossed these animals with transgenic optogenetic mice so that we could optically stimulate brain circuits in different stages of Alzheimer's. Task two in phase three was running experiments with these animals and tracking changes in the blood flow response to neural stimulation. We accomplished the first task of phase three and started the second task when the timeline of the project came to an end. This was an EAGER project with limited timeline and budget for such a complex project (since the project received funding from other resources, the project continued after this grant). Another factor that made the plan, specifically the experimental work, more complex, was the pandemic which limited our access to the lab and the animal models we prepared for the experiments. Nonetheless, during the pandemic, we used the time to improve the design of our tomography platform and we developed a machine learning based algorithm to optimize the scanning process for tomography systems which allows us to speed up the process of data acquisition in imaging. The outcome of this work was also two other journal publications in the field of optics.

The technology that was developed for this project and the experiments which were conducted to develop the model helped us better understand the coupling between neural and vascular networks in the brain which is altered under Alzheimer’s and this change can be used in future for early detection of Alzheimer’s by testing the effect in tissue that can be imaged non-invasively such as retina. The impact of that could be significant.

The budget was used to partially support four PhD students. Two PhD students finished their program during this period, and they were replaced by two new PhD students. The project also provided research opportunity for a master student who finished his thesis working on the project and two undergraduate students who worked under the supervision of PhD students and helped them with the development of software for automated data acquisition and analysis.

The infrastructure developed in this project helped the research team to receive two federal grants to continue this work, one from the national institute of health and one from the national science foundation. At the time of submitting this report, Alzheimer’s research and specifically the study of changes in neurovascular coupling under Alzheimer’s is the main line of research in the lab and the work was initiated by this EAGER funding from the NSF.
